definitions.definition: every one (of), or the complete amount or number (of), or the whole (of):
examples: All animals have to eat in order to live.

definitions.definition: considering all the different parts of the situation together:
examples: All in all, I think you've done very well.

definitions.definition: used when you make a comment or criticism, so that it seems less severe or is less likely to offend someone:
examples: All I'm saying is I think the end part could have been a little shorter.

definitions.definition: the only and small amount or number of something you have:
examples: Her parents died when she was a baby, so I was all the family she ever had.
The cake was all eaten last night.

definitions.definition: used after a number to mean that both teams or players in a game have equal points:
examples: The score at half-time was still four all.
The game was all but over by the time we arrived.
It was a ghastly business all round.

definitions.definition: even or much better, stronger, more exciting, etc.:
examples: She felt all the better for the drink.

definitions.definition: used in front of many nouns to form adjectives meaning "every", "every type of", or "the whole of" that particular thing:
examples: an all-night bar (= a bar that is open for the whole night)

definitions.definition: used in front of many adjectives and present participles to mean "everything" or "everyone":
used in front of many nouns and adjectives to mean "completely":
examples: all-cotton socks (= socks that are made completely of cotton)
